commit_message:
Use osc-lib instead of openstackclient

osc-lib is a package of common support modules for writing
OSC plugins. All common functions, classes such as exceptions,
utils, logs and so on have been moved from openstackclient to
osc-lib.

So use osc-lib instead of openstackclient.

Change-Id: I8041ad5c9ff9b3c0ff772e632f401c638bb293b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-mistralclient refs/changes/39/333739/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from osc_lib import utils

subject: Keystone liberty mitaka upgrade step
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-06 12:57:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/28bb086828990461ccca27a48a9fd334d0a6c15b', 'message': '[WIP] Add update path for keystone to be moved under wsgi

With change Ie26908ac9bfc0b84b6b65ae3bda711236b03d9d4 we moved all
services to depend on an openstack-core core service. This part
will take care of the upgrade from existing Liberty installations to
Mitaka ones.

NB: The WIP is because I have not tested the script via tripleo (only by
hand) yet.  The testing by hand was done by deploying a system without
the keystone-under-wsgi change and then running the script

Change-Id: If85672afa8a92de2a1c0a222d28682fd100bcf7d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-08 18:01:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/b5367ef5d531356c920d5f062ac31f65c4d883e6', 'message': "Keystone liberty mitaka upgrade step

This step needs to be run after the major-upgrade-pacemaker-init.yaml
step. It is split in more parts:

1) Here we run a small puppet manifest that configures keystone to be
run under httpd. This part does not restart httpd at all because doing
so before turning off the openstack-keystone resource would fail
due to both services wanting to listen on the same ports.

2) In this step we add a dummy openstack-core resource, delete the
openstack-keystone resource and make sure that all the resources that
were previously depending on keystone now depend on the dummy resource.

FIXME: need to verify if the constraint changes make httpd restart or
not. If they do, then nothing else is needed. If they don't we need to
add a third step

The rationale for doing the whole keystone migration in this single step
is that it will be verifiable on its own.

Depend-On: I8cb4cb3193e6b823aad48ad7dbbbb227364d2a58

Change-Id: If85672afa8a92de2a1c0a222d28682fd100bcf7d
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-06-09 06:54:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/877f4ca11a5c6848adec52a181487fc3b3c4ed94', 'message': "Keystone liberty mitaka upgrade step

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-06-10 12:40:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/9fd8c50e6dc96493a670e050d0f0794f31b3365d', 'message': 'Keystone liberty mitaka upgrade step

This step needs to be run after the major-upgrade-pacemaker-init.yaml
step and after the liberty->mitaka aodh upgrade step.
It is split in more parts:

1) Here we run a small puppet manifest that configures keystone to be
run under httpd. This part does not restart httpd at all because doing
so before turning off the openstack-keystone resource would fail
due to both services wanting to listen on the same ports.

2) In this step we add a dummy openstack-core resource, delete the
openstack-keystone resource and make sure that all the resources that
were previously depending on keystone now depend on the dummy resource.

3) We restart httpd to make sure the changes are taking place.

The rationale for doing the whole keystone migration in this single step
is that it will be verifiable on its own. We also need to add both
the aodh and the horizon apache configuration to make sure we do not
remove any services from httpd during the upgrade.

Depend-On: I8cb4cb3193e6b823aad48ad7dbbbb227364d2a58

Change-Id: If85672afa8a92de2a1c0a222d28682fd100bcf7d

commit_message:
Keystone liberty mitaka upgrade step

This step needs to be run after the major-upgrade-pacemaker-init.yaml
step and after the liberty->mitaka aodh upgrade step.
It is split in more parts:

1) Here we run a small puppet manifest that configures keystone to be
run under httpd. This part does not restart httpd at all because doing
so before turning off the openstack-keystone resource would fail
due to both services wanting to listen on the same ports.

2) In this step we add a dummy openstack-core resource, delete the
openstack-keystone resource and make sure that all the resources that
were previously depending on keystone now depend on the dummy resource.

3) We restart httpd to make sure the changes are taking place.

The rationale for doing the whole keystone migration in this single step
is that it will be verifiable on its own. We also need to add both
the aodh and the horizon apache configuration to make sure we do not
remove any services from httpd during the upgrade.

Partial-Bug: #1579705

Depends-On: I8cb4cb3193e6b823aad48ad7dbbbb227364d2a58
Depends-On: I22a348c298ff44f616b2e898f4872eddea040239

Change-Id: If85672afa8a92de2a1c0a222d28682fd100bcf7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/35/302235/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function liberty_to_mitaka_keystone { # The CIBs are saved under /root as they might contain sensitive data CIB="/root/migration.cib" CIB_BACKUP="/root/backup.cib" # If the "openstack-core-clone" resource already exists we do not need to make this transition # as the function needs to be idempotent if pcs resource show "openstack-core-clone"; then return 0 fi rm -f "$CIB" "$CIB_BACKUP" || /bin/true # Create dummy resource pcs resource create openstack-core ocf:heartbeat:Dummy --clone pcs cluster cib "$CIB" # We keep a copy of the original CIB for debugging reasons cp "$CIB" "$CIB_BACKUP" # change all constraints from keystone to dummy CONSTR="$(pcs -f "$CIB" config | grep keystone | grep start | grep then)" echo "$CONSTR" | { while read i; do ACT=$(echo "$i" | awk '{print $1}') SRC=$(echo "$i" | awk '{print $2}') DST=$(echo "$i" | awk '{print $5}') CID=$(echo "$i" | awk '{print $7}' | sed -e 's/.*id\://g' -e 's/)//g') if [ "$SRC" == "openstack-keystone-clone" ]; then pcs -f "$CIB" constraint order $ACT openstack-core-clone then $DST else pcs -f "$CIB" constraint order $ACT $SRC then openstack-core-clone fi pcs -f "$CIB" constraint remove $CID done; } # make sure keystone and httpd are started after dummy pcs -f "$CIB" constraint order start openstack-core-clone then openstack-keystone-clone pcs -f "$CIB" constraint order start openstack-core-clone then httpd-clone # This takes core of removing the delay-clone which does nothing in mitaka # related THT change is here https://review.openstack.org/#/c/285207/ pcs -f "$CIB" resource delete delay-clone # push the changes pcs cluster cib-push "$CIB" }

commit_message:
Add net config override

Adds the ability to override the os-net-config data for the undercloud.
In some cases, a single bridge with a single physical interface may not
be sufficient for all cases. This will allow for more advanced
customization of the undercloud networking.

The path to a custom os-net-config json template can be specificed in
undercloud.conf with the net_config_override option.

Change-Id: I1fdc62d61eb5d2ea7e9418e40aa8c07173169d35

commit_message:
Add support for a header requesting that the storlet run on proxy.

This is beneficial for helping to make sure that storlets operate properly
not just on the object nodes, but on the proxy nodes as well.

This could also be used when comparing the performance of running on the
object node vs. running on proxy node.

Change-Id: Iec14cfbaeed709f3b1d81b5b6926d68d56022e6c

commit_message:
Use upper-constraints in tox test environments

Recently OpenStack introduced a mechanism to specify a constrained
"working set" of packages that are "guaranteed" to produce a working
OpenStack environment. This pinning of packages limits the more
broadly-defined requirements.txt which is managed by
global-requirements.

This patch modifies our tox test environment to use upper-constraints
and explictly removes those requirements from the "venv" tox
environment that is used by some commands in infra.

Conflicts:
    tox.ini

This is due to Ia1be8f60265d9dab2639a05912b4b7c51f1d4033 not being on
the stable/mitaka branch

Change-Id: I84582370e139fc5812bc85ae5341f7f9c8b93ff5
Related-Bug: 1554791
(cherry picked from commit 315958aab8273cd2dbfdd617b173d5c063a88948)
(cherry picked from commit e34762d77714dcc8e10e17d9d252dbca4efffac7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/57/330957/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = pip install -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt?h=stable/liberty} {opts} {packages}# NOTE(from nova tox.ini by jaegerandi): This target does not use constraints # because upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages}# NOTE(from nova tox.ini by jaegerandi): This target does not use constraints # because upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
libvirt: split out code for determining if migration should abort

There are two timeouts that can cause migration to be aborted,
one looks to see if forward progress is being made, while the
other checks an overall time limit. Split out the code for
checking these limits into a separate method and add some
explicit unit testing for the scenarios they encounter.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-clean-driver
Change-Id: I115fc7f0b41840244f7e60dcb733062209f9460b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/62/327762/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_live_migration_abort_stuck(self): # Progress time exceeds progress timeout self.assertTrue(migration.should_abort(self.instance, 5000, 1000, 2000, 4500, 9000)) def test_live_migration_abort_no_prog_timeout(self): # Progress timeout is disabled self.assertFalse(migration.should_abort(self.instance, 5000, 1000, 0, 4500, 9000)) def test_live_migration_abort_not_stuck(self): # Progress time is less than progress timeout self.assertFalse(migration.should_abort(self.instance, 5000, 4500, 2000, 4500, 9000)) def test_live_migration_abort_too_long(self): # Elapsed time is over completion timeout self.assertTrue(migration.should_abort(self.instance, 5000, 4500, 2000, 4500, 2000)) def test_live_migration_abort_no_comp_timeout(self): # Completion timeout is disabled self.assertFalse(migration.should_abort(self.instance, 5000, 4500, 2000, 4500, 0)) def test_live_migration_abort_still_working(self): # Elapsed time is less than completion timeout self.assertFalse(migration.should_abort(self.instance, 5000, 4500, 2000, 4500, 9000))

subject: Second endpoint type default is not None
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 23:08:59.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/9b0553da5a6b8d89c2cbd28c97e06b3ded85e132', 'message': 'Second endpoint type default is not None

According to the help for SECONDARY_ENDPOINT_TYPE, the default
value is None. However the default given in the local_settings
example is publicURL, which makes the documentaiton a little
confusing.

Change-Id: I20c507e5b42f9c6000de94fcf1a51bb5437bf43f
'}]
commit_message:
Second endpoint type default is not None

According to the help for SECONDARY_ENDPOINT_TYPE, the default
value is None. However the default given in the local_settings
example is publicURL, which makes the documentaiton a little
confusing.

Change-Id: I20c507e5b42f9c6000de94fcf1a51bb5437bf43f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/11/334111/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # external to the OpenStack environment. The default is None. This#SECONDARY_ENDPOINT_TYPE = None
deleted_lines: # external to the OpenStack environment. The default is None. This#SECONDARY_ENDPOINT_TYPE = "publicURL"

commit_message:
[cli-ref] Update python-monascaclient to 1.1.0

Change-Id: I53c085f0852a5524f24b29b4b1e9e1ef57d6c152
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/34/334234/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This chapter documents :command:`monasca` version ``1.1.0``. [--os-project-domain-id OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID] [--os-project-domain-name OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME] metric-name-list``--os-project-domain-id OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID`` Defaults to ``env[OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID]``. ``--os-project-domain-name OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME`` Defaults to ``env[OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME]``. [--match-by <MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY1,MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY2,...>]``--match-by <MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY1,MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY2,...>`` The metric dimensions to use to create unique alarms. One or more dimension key names separated by a comma. Key names need quoting when they contain special chars [&,(,),{,},>,<] that confuse the CLI parser. values are id, name, severity, created_at, updated_at. Fields may be followed by "asc" or "desc", ex "severity desc", to set the direction of sorting. <MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY1,MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY2,...>``<MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY1,MATCH_BY_DIMENSION_KEY2,...>`` The metric dimensions to use to create unique alarms. One or more dimension key names separated by a comma. Key names need quoting when they contain special chars [&,(,),{,},>,<] that confuse the CLI parser. [--group_by <KEY1,KEY2,...>] [--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>]``--group_by <KEY1,KEY2,...>`` Select which keys to use for grouping. A '\*' groups by all keys. ``--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>`` Retrieve data for the specified tenant/project id instead of the tenant/project from the user's Keystone credentials. [--limit <RETURN LIMIT>] [--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>]``--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>`` Retrieve data for the specified tenant/project id instead of the tenant/project from the user's Keystone credentials. .. _monasca_metric-name-list: monasca metric-name-list ------------------------ .. code-block:: console usage: monasca metric-name-list [--dimensions <KEY1=VALUE1,KEY2=VALUE2...>] [--offset <OFFSET LOCATION>] [--limit <RETURN LIMIT>] [--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>] **Optional arguments:** ``--dimensions <KEY1=VALUE1,KEY2=VALUE2...>`` key value pair used to specify a metric dimension. This can be specified multiple times, or once with parameters separated by a comma. Dimensions need quoting when they contain special chars [&,(,),{,},>,<] that confuse the CLI parser. ``--offset <OFFSET LOCATION>`` The offset used to paginate the return data. ``--limit <RETURN LIMIT>`` The amount of data to be returned up to the API maximum limit. ``--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>`` Retrieve data for the specified tenant/project id instead of the tenant/project from the user's Keystone credentials. [--group_by <KEY1,KEY2,...>] [--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>]``--group_by <KEY1,KEY2,...>`` Select which keys to use for grouping. A '\*' groups by all keys. ``--tenant-id <TENANT_ID>`` Retrieve data for the specified tenant/project id instead of the tenant/project from the user's Keystone credentials. usage: monasca notification-create [--period <PERIOD>] <NOTIFICATION_NAME> <TYPE> <ADDRESS>**Optional arguments:** ``--period <PERIOD>`` A period for the notification method. Can only be non zero with webhooks usage: monasca notification-list [--sort-by <SORT BY FIELDS>] [--offset <OFFSET LOCATION>]``--sort-by <SORT BY FIELDS>`` Fields to sort by as a comma separated list. Valid values are id, name, type, address, created_at, updated_at. Fields may be followed by "asc" or "desc", ex "address desc", to set the direction of sorting. <TYPE> <ADDRESS> <PERIOD>``<PERIOD>`` A period for the notification method. Can only be non zero with webhooks
deleted_lines: This chapter documents :command:`monasca` version ``1.0.30``. [--os-domain-id OS_DOMAIN_ID] [--os-domain-name OS_DOMAIN_NAME]``--os-domain-id OS_DOMAIN_ID`` Defaults to ``env[OS_DOMAIN_ID]``. ``--os-domain-name OS_DOMAIN_NAME`` Defaults to ``env[OS_DOMAIN_NAME]``. [--match-by <DIMENSION_KEY1,DIMENSION_KEY2,...>]``--match-by <DIMENSION_KEY1,DIMENSION_KEY2,...>`` The metric dimensions to match to the alarm dimensions. One or more dimension key names separated by a comma. Key names need quoting when they contain special chars [&,(,),{,},>,<] that confuse the CLI parser. values are id, name, severity, updated_timestamp, created_timestamp. Fields may be followed by "asc" or "desc", ex "severity desc", to set the direction of sorting. <DIMENSION_KEY1,DIMENSION_KEY2,...>``<DIMENSION_KEY1,DIMENSION_KEY2,...>`` The metric dimensions to match to the alarm dimensions. One or more dimension key names separated by a comma. Key names need quoting when they contain special chars [&,(,),{,},>,<] that confuse the CLI parser. [--limit <RETURN LIMIT>] usage: monasca notification-create <NOTIFICATION_NAME> <TYPE> <ADDRESS> usage: monasca notification-list [--offset <OFFSET LOCATION>] <TYPE> <ADDRESS>

commit_message:
Waiting for Neutron port to become ACTIVE

This patch set adds two config options similar to those
used in Nova, namely vif_plugging_is_fatal and
vif_plugging_timeout to make it possible to ask Kuryr
to wait until the port status becomes Active during libnetwork
join operations.

Closes-Bug: #1578016

Change-Id: I106d2c8c289c7fca2a465c72f1dbd53acc539f39
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/84/319484/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time app.vif_plug_is_fatal = cfg.CONF.neutron_client.vif_plugging_is_fatal app.vif_plug_timeout = cfg.CONF.neutron_client.vif_plugging_timeout port_down = True t_end = time.time() + app.vif_plug_timeout while True: try: iport = app.neutron.list_ports(name=neutron_port_name) except n_exceptions.NeutronClientException as ex: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): app.logger.error(_LE('Could not list the port ' 'during the join operation: {0}.') .format(ex)) num_ports = len(iport.get('ports', [])) if num_ports > 1: raise exceptions.DuplicatedResourceException( "Multiple Neutron ports exist for the params {0}" .format(neutron_port_name)) elif num_ports < 1: raise exceptions.NoResourceException( "No Neutron port exists for the params {0}" .format(neutron_port_name)) if iport['ports'][0]['status'] == 'ACTIVE': port_down = False if (time.time() < t_end) and port_down: time.sleep(1) else: break if port_down and app.vif_plug_is_fatal: raise exceptions.NoResourceException( "Neutron networks did not become active on time {0}" .format(neutron_port_name))

verify-full-discover-resources job for more test coverage.

commit_message:
Add driver compliance checks to check pipeline

Cinder's tox now includes a 'compliance' target for validating
all Cinder drivers conform to the minimum interface requirements.

This adds a job to run those complance checks to catch and changes
that would make a driver out of compliance for our minimum feature
set.

Change-Id: Ic39b8c73e5acb3e7e4f756496e83189fbdcb0623

commit_message:
Correct naming inconsistency in DBNotifyInterface.

when remove a router port, method "remove_router_port" will be called 
by the dispatcher. However, DBNotifyInterface defines a wrong method 
"delete_router_port".

Change-Id: If155b7ce484d9f1afa7f7b721ae42f4bf36752be

want to install.

commit_message:
libvirt: split out code for detecting live migration job type

When we see a job type of "NONE", we have code to convert that
to another more useful job type. Split this code out into its
own method to make it easier to test it in isolation. This new
testing exposed a bug in log debug messages where the 'ex'
parameter was not being correctly passed in a dict.

Refactoring of mocking in migration tests in test_driver.py is
left as a future exercise once this whole series is merged.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-clean-driver
Change-Id: I80e5b2c22a03556bfce29a74ae304cef6b6841cb

subject: Stop using a global logger for all the things
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-26 22:52:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/4f5bace9b97491ffc0a0bdabc9fa74932aa433d7', 'message': 'Stop using a global logger for all the things

Instead of using the same logger for all the things
which makes it incredibly hard to figure out what the
images and there builds are doing; instead have it so
that each image gets its own logger which is then used
by tasks that process that image.

Each images logs now will go to a logs directory that
can be more easily read and looked over and leaves the
main logger for informational/task kind of output only.

commit_message:
Stop using a global logger for all the things

Instead of using the same logger for all the things
which makes it incredibly hard to figure out what the images
and there builds are doing; instead have it so that each
image gets its own logger which is then used by tasks that
process that image.

Each images logs now will (optionally) go to a logs directory
that can be more easily read and looked over and leaves
the main logger for informational/task kind of
output only.

Closes-Bug: #1586478

Change-Id: I939e073a2bc5ed8b5a1e969888fc743d80f468c9

commit_message:
Handle locales install on Fedora 24

Fedora 24 has split locales into separate packages.  Testing revealed
what is possibly a bug in the choosing of default packages, so add a
small work-around to ensure the minimal locale pack is installed.

This appears to be the only change required for fedora-minimal with
Fedora 24; at least to build with the project-config infra elements.

Change-Id: I64438c34c572ed96211384ae1bfb45b2949e4318
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/18/333118/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _lang_pack="" if [ $DISTRO_NAME = "fedora" -a $DIB_RELEASE -le 23 ]; then # _install_langs is a rpm macro that limits the translation # files, etc installed by packages. For Fedora 23 [1], the # glibc-common package will obey this to only install the # listed locales, keeping things much smaller (we still have # to clean up locales manually on centos7). We install just # en_US because people often ssh in with that locale, but # leave out everything else. Note that yum has an option to # set this from the command-line [2], but the yum in trusty we # are using is too old to have it. So we set it directly in # the macros file # # [1] http://pkgs.fedoraproject.org/cgit/rpms/glibc.git/commit/glibc.spec?h=f23&id=91764bd9ec690d4b8a886c0a3a104aac12d340d2 # [2] http://yum.baseurl.org/gitweb?p=yum.git;a=commit;h=26128173b362474456e8f0642073ecb0322ed031 echo "%_install_langs C:en_US:en_US.UTF-8" >> $HOME/.rpmmacros elif [ $DISTRO_NAME = "fedora" -a $DIB_RELEASE -gt 24 ]; then # glibc on F24 has split locales into "langpack" packages. By # default the dependencies should bring in the # minimal-langpack, but there seems to be a bug (rhbz#1349258) # where it chooses glibc-langpack-zu instead. Work-around # this by explicitly requring the minimal pack. _lang_pack="glibc-minimal-langpack" fi install $@ ${_lang_pack} && rc=$? || rc=$? # install dnf for >= f22
deleted_lines: # Fedora 24 has a much better way to handle just installing some # languages; see bug. We should support that at the right time. if [[ $DISTRO_NAME == "fedora" && $DIB_RELEASE -gt 23 ]]; then echo "Locale support for Fedora 24 is incomplete" echo " see: https://bugs.launchpad.net/diskimage-builder/+bug/1571488" die "Cannot cleanup locales on > Fedora 23" fi # _install_langs is a rpm macro that limits the translation # files, etc installed by packages. For Fedora 23 [1], the # glibc-common package will obey this to only install the # listed locales, keeping things much smaller (we still have # to clean up locales manually on centos7). We install just # en_US because people often ssh in with that locale, but # leave out everything else. Note that yum has an option to # set this from the command-line [2], but the yum in trusty we # are using is too old to have it. So we set it directly in # the macros file # # [1] http://pkgs.fedoraproject.org/cgit/rpms/glibc.git/commit/glibc.spec?h=f23&id=91764bd9ec690d4b8a886c0a3a104aac12d340d2 # [2] http://yum.baseurl.org/gitweb?p=yum.git;a=commit;h=26128173b362474456e8f0642073ecb0322ed031 echo "%_install_langs C:en_US:en_US.UTF-8" >> $HOME/.rpmmacros install $@ && rc=$? || rc=$? # install dnf for >= f22

commit_message:
Backport 'Support https keystone CA checking '

https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1537783
was fixed in master and stable/mitaka branch, however
there are some conflict in cherrypick the patch
to stable/liberty, so a manual copy the several lines
changes to stable/liberty branch, thus all user
who has problem in https connections on liberty
branch can benefit from that.

Change-Id: I9ed459befdd0090148147693303dd48efc9de6f5
Related-Bug: 1537783

commit_message:
Make live migration checks async

This change makes the checks that happen before a live migration
non-blocking so that the user can receive an HTTP accepted and
later check the results of the live-migration via instance-actions.

bp: async-live-migration-rest-check

Change-Id: I4f788d48ec0e166898184842ac55560163c1b343

commit_message:
Moves auth plugin test setup closer to its use

Way too many tests were running auth plugin setup/cleanup. If you don't
use it then don't run it.

Change-Id: Ia668b249621638d0759220843e55e9a279ec8387

commit_message:
Don't use stored context to reset stacks

The resetting of in-progress stacks at startup is done using an admin
context. No user actions (e.g. ReST API calls) are performed, so there is
no need to load the user context that is stored with the stack. (Nor is
the
current context rewritten to the database in the process of resetting the
state.)

Since loading the user context from the DB may result in a call to the
keystone API, eliminating this ensures that stacks can be reset
successfully even if heat-engine starts before keystone is available.

Also there is no need to resolve outputs data while reset stacks, so set
resolve_data=False when load stack.

Change-Id: I9379ef6cc6f1d3bbc2569ff2150795bfaffee430
Closes-Bug: #1570569

commit_message:
do not create namespace if snat is disabled

Add a setting of l3_agent.ini to skip create qrouter/snat
namespaces on snat host if snat is disabled.

Change-Id: If7f2176ef81fb4a767f530e1bbe87669458bd45b
DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1518296

Change-Id: I1d59ed9089def808bab31d97ba4cba9e8592b568

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/44/333744/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not container: self.module.fail_json( msg="No such container: {} to stop".format(name)) else: if not container['Status'].startswith('Exited '): self.changed = True self.dc.stop(name)
deleted_lines: if not container['Status'].startswith('Exited '): self.changed = True self.dc.stop(name)

commit_message:
policy: Replaces 'authorize' in nova-api (part 1)

Updates nova.api.openstack.compute modules to use the
context's 'can' method instead of the existing
'authorize' function.

Co-Authored-By: Andrew Laski <andrew@lascii.com>

Change-Id: I834cff54c1bc079b566cb66b4173d4cf109bc686
Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/33/330033/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def can(self, rule, target=None): if target is None: target = {'project_id': self.project_id, 'user_id': self.user_id} return policy.authorize(self, rule, target)

commit_message:
objects: Add devices_metadata to instance object

Loading the InstanceDeviceMetadata object into the
instance will avoid the need to make multiple calls
to the db from the metadata service.

Partially implements blueprint virt-device-role-tagging
Change-Id: Iea73c26e48d02c9fda9426c8603d1627c0e8e692

commit_message:
Make print py3 compatible

In PY3,remove the print "", join the print () function to achieve
the same function,this patch is to fix it.

Change-Id: Ie860e912b0c7101fd9d1d5c8373db8688f99122c
Closes-Bug: #1595773
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/333669/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: print ("usage: %s <SR PATH> <print|delete|move>" % sys.argv[0]) print ("error: must specify where to move bad VHDs") print (bad_vhd)
deleted_lines: print "usage: %s <SR PATH> <print|delete|move>" % sys.argv[0] print "error: must specify where to move bad VHDs" print bad_vhd

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).
The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).
This patch fix the issue.

Change-Id: Id14676d8d07953fd33139a8fd8b7773aabf5fdfa
Partial-Bug: #1259292

commit_message:
Replace safe_utils.getcallargs with inspect.getcallargs

safe_utils.getcallargs was written to support python2.6 which did not
have inspect.getcallargs. Now that support for python2.6 has been
dropped it should be replaced with inspect.getcallargs. Note:The
interface that safe_utils.getcallargs provides did not match
inspect.getcallargs around the handling of the self parameter needing to
be passed in. It should be brought inline with inspect.getcallargs so
that it can be dropped. Nova fixed in 2910d75b28afd909af3b4ac392729ac3d5e64b65.

Change-Id: I96d54c07f42d46807e90ee4a38a7a7cef3bc23b9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/46/333746/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import inspect call_dict = inspect.getcallargs(f, self, context, *args, **kw)

commit_message:
Don't create network during API and functional tests

Tempest will create network for each tests, since we don't
use real driver for API or functional tests, so we don't need to
create real network.

Change-Id: I6a28b1e81a5dbe9228ce273ba555889446f31369
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/85/329285/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: network_resources = { 'network': False, 'router': False, 'subnet': False, 'dhcp': False, }

subject: Make enforce_type with True by default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 05:34:06.000000000', 'files': ['zun/tests/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zun/commit/7171dd78daa0c021e78896152e29a68e921ff81f', 'message': "Make enforce_type with True by default

Method CONF.set_override is used for changing config option's value
with designated value in unit test. Each config option has limitation
for type and value. In production code, oslo.config can ensure user's
input is valid, but in unit test, test methods can pass if we use
method CONF.set_override without parameter enforce_type=True even
we pass wrong type or wrong value to config option.

This commit makes sure calling method CONF.set_override with
enforce_type=True to avoid invalid tests.

Related-Bug: #1517839
Change-Id: I7b426fc8d5fc90f4df4eefa7dea5d11830d209ff
"}]
commit_message:
Make enforce_type with True by default

Method CONF.set_override is used for changing config option's value
with designated value in unit test. Each config option has limitation
for type and value. In production code, oslo.config can ensure user's
input is valid, but in unit test, test methods can pass if we use
method CONF.set_override without parameter enforce_type=True even
we pass wrong type or wrong value to config option.

This commit makes sure calling method CONF.set_override with
enforce_type=True to avoid invalid tests.

Related-Bug: #1517839
Change-Id: I7b426fc8d5fc90f4df4eefa7dea5d11830d209ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/41/333741/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.set_override(k, v, group, enforce_type=True)

commit_message:
Don't need alliases of rpc backend for messaging

Zun doesn't have previous version, so don't need
backward compatibility for messaging.

Change-Id: I2810afa2d841cee89445f3ef1165735bac41d2d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/63/333763/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: transport = messaging.get_transport(cfg.CONF) allowed_remote_exmods=exmods)
deleted_lines: # NOTE(asalkeld): # The zun.openstack.common.rpc entries are for compatibility # with devstack rpc_backend configuration values. TRANSPORT_ALIASES = { 'zun.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu': 'rabbit', 'zun.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid': 'qpid', 'zun.openstack.common.rpc.impl_zmq': 'zmq', } transport = messaging.get_transport(cfg.CONF, aliases=TRANSPORT_ALIASES) allowed_remote_exmods=exmods, aliases=TRANSPORT_ALIASES)

commit_message:
Fix docker daemon proxy support in vagrant

There was an unwanted line break in the systemd file preventing the proxy from
being configured correctly.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I3e6413d4f2d373951cb558e0af1b8bc92d4cbb91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/38/333238/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: glance-*, fix rabbit config with ceilometer
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-26 00:17:39.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/glance/templates/glance-registry.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/glance/templates/glance-api.conf.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/2a2a86ac43f86ee698ce080486612984f67d9ea0', 'message': 'glance-*, fix rabbit config with ceilometer

Currently, if ceilometer is enabled with glance then the
rabbitmq is non-functional, causing various glance failures
including image upload.

This is caused because:
The generated config fails to have a carriage return at the
end of the rabbit_host line, causing the following line to
be added to this entry.

rabbit_host is used rather than rabbit_hosts, where the
fromer expects a string, rather than the list that is
provided.

This also adds rabbit HA support, to be in-line with the
other services using rabbitmq.

This is resolved, by pushing the rabbit_hosts entry to be
last, meaning that a carriage return is not required.

Change-Id: I89f26d542565b98025fd9b84fc4beb5cbed364e5
Closes-Bug: 1596244
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <email@daviey.com>
'}]
commit_message:
glance-*, fix rabbit config with ceilometer

Currently, if ceilometer is enabled with glance then the
rabbitmq is non-functional, causing various glance failures
including image upload.

This is caused because:
The generated config fails to have a carriage return at the
end of the rabbit_host line, causing the following line to
be added to this entry.

rabbit_host is used rather than rabbit_hosts, where the
fromer expects a string, rather than the list that is
provided.

This also adds rabbit HA support, to be in-line with the
other services using rabbitmq.

This is resolved, by pushing the rabbit_hosts entry to be
last, meaning that a carriage return is not required.

Change-Id: I89f26d542565b98025fd9b84fc4beb5cbed364e5
Closes-Bug: 1596244
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <email@daviey.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/05/334205/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rabbit_ha_queues = true rabbit_hosts = {% for host in groups['rabbitmq'] %}{{ hostvars[host]['ansible_' + hostvars[host]['api_interface']]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rabbitmq_port }}{% if not loop.last %},{% endif %}{% endfor %}
deleted_lines: rabbit_host = {% for host in groups['rabbitmq'] %}{{ hostvars[host]['ansible_' + hostvars[host]['api_interface']]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rabbitmq_port }}{% if not loop.last %},{% endif %}{% endfor %}

commit_message:
Neutron-LBaaS: Fix network_resources path

* upstream tempest changed the namespace for
  network_resources, this change updates that path
* fixed changed deprecated config parameters
* replaced network_cilent passed into DeletableSubnet
  with subnets_client and routers_client

Change-Id: I12e627398ec738fcb891dda8985273014324ae33
Closes-Bug: #1581660
(cherry picked from commit 0b6a3fbdfab9768287205d278061a63204869e5d)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-25 02:41:35.000000000', 'files': ['heatclient/tests/functional/osc/v1/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/e84621ecc0e3c774a031ea6d29875a9313008bd0', 'message': "Replace dict.iteritems with six.iteritems to make PY3 compatible

Python3 do not use dict.iteritems, which would raise AttributeError: 'dict'

Closes-Bug: #1596124
"}]
commit_message:
Replace dict.iteritems with six.iteritems to make PY3 compatible

Python3 do not use dict.iteritems, which would raise AttributeError: 'dict'
object has no attribute 'iteritems'.

Change-Id: I75f5954ce0d5573f69a22799dacb74b918028115
Closes-Bug: #1596124
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/29/334129/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return dict((self._key_name(k), v) for k, v in six.iteritems(obj)) return dict((self._key_name(k), v) for k, v in six.iteritems(obj))
deleted_lines: return dict((self._key_name(k), v) for k, v in obj.iteritems()) return dict((self._key_name(k), v) for k, v in obj.iteritems())

commit_message:
Add 'description_text' filed to test_table_struct_env_show

According to this commit: Ic7dc5f420f453a3f4fa2769860b4a603ab14eaad,
add a new field to env, So add this field to test_table_struct_env_show
to pass the test.

Change-Id: I6a721f8382968a0efa80c95c09879435d406996f

commit_message:
Fixes for a packaging error

The xstatic-release script didn't tell the setup.py
to include data files in installation. This release
incorporates that fix (and an unintentional
change to the LICENSE).

This skips to the 8 BUILD because the 7th BUILD was
emergency released to fix the packaging error.

Change-Id: I3223f0f0c4387ad64068c3924eb634df6f0d3dcf

revisions:

commit_message:
Fix confusion between Neutron and FWaaS versions

This documentation is about FWaaS v1.0. I guess the confusion
comes from the v2.0 prefix in endpoint URLs. The version in
the URLs maches the Neutron version.

Change-Id: Ic29e9f93492f7a65a22ddb64ddbcd9bf273883f6
Signed-off-by: Guillaume Giamarchi <guillaume.giamarchi@gmail.com>

deleted_lines: <section xml:id="fwaas-v2.0"> <title>FWaaS v2.0 (CURRENT) (fw, firewalls, firewall_policies, firewall_rules)</title> Use the Firewall-as-a-Service (FWaaS) v2.0 extension to deploy

commit_message:
Added 200 response code to the List API versions.

The description for the response of the API says:
This operation does not accept a request body and does not return a response body.
But the API does return a response. The description should be:
This operation does not accept a request body.

Change-Id: I610198a1c83654f215a70015bc58cf27930d557e
Closes-Bug: #1539467

commit_message:
X-Timestamp header updates on openstack-api-site response

Extra X-Timestamp header is removed from Container
DELETE "404 Not Found" response.

Depends-On: I4837fb70db2df29267ea081949bcc556a625bc45

commit_message:
Add basic image sharing information

Add a few sentances desribing the imaging sharing concepts before
the operations are detailed. This chage is in conjunction with the
depends-on change noted below in the openstack-manuals repo.

Closes-Bug: #1521158
Depends-on I9c0af79079d01a536ac57ec4c7a9a8f22bbf75a2

Change-Id: I3bfa03491b951805d81b7df47b7dbf0ffa0befe3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/67/327167/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Image producers create and share images with image consumers, allowing the consumers to use the shared image when booting a server. The producer shares an image with the consumer by making the consumer a member of that image. The consumer then accepts or rejects the image by changing the image member status. After it is accepted, the image appears in the consumer's image list.

commit_message:
objects: new InstanceDeviceMetadata object

The InstanceDeviceMetadata will keep a list
of all the devices metadata, such as NICs and disks
associated to an instance. Eventually, it will be
stored in the instance_extra table.
InstanceDeviceMetadata object is new in this series
and has never been sent over RPC nor used.

Partially implements blueprint virt-device-role-tagging
Co-authored-by: Artom Lifshitz <alifshit@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I914e2c9a465864e5d320f8eb8d2fd509e64a7a75
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/318884/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'address': fields.USBAddressField(nullable=True), 'address': fields.SCSIAddressField(nullable=True), 'address': fields.IDEAddressField(nullable=True),class InstanceDevicesMetadata(base.NovaObject, base.NovaObjectDictCompat): 'instance_uuid': obj_fields.UUIDField(), 'devices_metadata': fields.ListOfObjectsField('DeviceMetadata', @base.remotable def create(self): values = {'devices_metadata': self._to_json()} db.instance_extra_update_by_uuid(self._context, self.instance_uuid, values) self.obj_reset_changes() @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_instance_uuid(cls, context, instance_uuid): db_extra = db.instance_extra_get_by_instance_uuid( context, instance_uuid, columns=['devices_metadata']) if not db_extra: return None return cls.obj_from_db_obj(instance_uuid, db_extra['devices_metadata']) def _to_json(self): return jsonutils.dumps(self.obj_to_primitive()) @classmethod def obj_from_primitive(cls, primitive, context=None): obj_topology = super(InstanceDevicesMetadata, cls).obj_from_primitive( primitive, context=None) return obj_topology @classmethod def obj_from_db_obj(cls, instance_uuid, db_obj): primitive = jsonutils.loads(db_obj) obj_topology = cls.obj_from_primitive(primitive) return obj_topology

commit_message:
db: add a device_metadata column to instance_extra

Adding a device_metadata column to store the virt_device_metadata object.

Partially implements blueprint virt-device-role-tagging
Co-authored-by: Artom Lifshitz <alifshit@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I035b188f706a8f371e9fbb94c605869ccaec462e

commit_message:
Huawei driver should return ceiling of volume size

The function manage_existing_get_size returns the floor of volume
size in huawei driver. But in the driver API:"When calculating the
size, round up to the next GB." This patch fixes it by returning
the ceiling of volume size.

Change-Id: I6ccbc096ecd1d0723204c2caca4684ec63baafbd
Closes-Bug: #1587421
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/99/323699/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import math size = float(lun_info.get('CAPACITY')) / constants.CAPACITY_UNIT return int(math.ceil(size))
deleted_lines: size = float(lun_info.get('CAPACITY')) // constants.CAPACITY_UNIT remainder = float(lun_info.get('CAPACITY')) % constants.CAPACITY_UNIT if int(remainder) > 0: msg = _("Volume size must be multiple of 1 GB.") raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=msg) return int(size)

subject: Nimble: Don't query all vols from DB in do_setup()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-06 08:54:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/ba20ba27f69aefcd260d026497bebcb3ca8827d0', 'message': "Nimble: Don't query all vols from DB in do_setup()

and then filter in the driver code.  It should be done by DB filtering

commit_message:
Nimble: Don't query all vols from DB in do_setup()

Nimble driver does a VolumeList.get_all() in its do_setup() method
and then filter in the driver code.  It should be done by DB filtering
(i.e. VolumeList.get_all_by_host()) instead.

The bigger problem is, Cinder driver should avoid interaction with DB
directly.  The DB query code was added as part of its manage/unmange
feature implementation (9c3e6aa9cd8702a16b7de69267bf994c7e421890),
not sure if that is really necessary.  Further cleanup will be done
in separate patch.

Change-Id: Iefd809a02d455d4248d11034c655dfc5f92bb235
Partial-bug: 1542610
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/60/277060/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: all_vols = volume.VolumeList.get_all_by_host( context, self.host) for vol in all_vols: try: self.APIExecutor.edit_vol( vol.name, UNMANAGE_EDIT_MASK, {'agent-type': AGENT_TYPE_OPENSTACK}) except NimbleAPIException: LOG.warning(_LW('Error updating agent-type for ' 'volume %s.'), vol.name)
deleted_lines: backend_name = self.configuration.safe_get('volume_backend_name') all_vols = volume.VolumeList.get_all( context, None, None, None, None, {'status': 'available'}) for vol in all_vols: if backend_name in vol.host: try: self.APIExecutor.edit_vol( vol.name, UNMANAGE_EDIT_MASK, {'agent-type': AGENT_TYPE_OPENSTACK}) except NimbleAPIException: LOG.warning(_LW('Error updating agent-type for ' 'volume %s.'), vol.name)

commit_message:
Make pip_lock_to_internal_repo a playbook var

When scoping pip_lock_to_internal_repo to each os_* role it was not
being applied correctly to the pip_install dependency of those roles.

Move pip_lock_to_internal_repo to the list of playbook scoped variables
so that the pip lockdown tasks are run as expected.

Change-Id: Ibd4f312b9b3174987b8bd319b3d5f15c397ec4a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/87/334087/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pip_lock_to_internal_repo: "{{ (pip_links | length) >= 1 }}"

commit_message:
Fix lack of client for midonet variant of l2gw

This patch supports l2 gateway cli for midonet l2gateway.

Note: L2gateway create CLI name of Midonet are different from that of
      networking-l2gw and includes "midonet-" prefix.

Change-Id: Ie1e3072bea09af6bdf528621326859322167f984
Closes-bug: #1580566

commit_message:
libvirt: add perf event support when create instance

Libvirt 1.3.3 has intergrated `perf`, which can be used as performance
statistics.

This patch enable perf event when create instances, the perf event
data can be collected by Ceilometer or other external monitor system.

Implement blueprint: support-perf-event

Co-Authored-By: Qiaowei Ren <qiaowei.ren@intel.com>

Change-Id: I2ffdabe40a7706cd5061a45f3e46c8245adb3b07

commit_message:
Add diffs for roles, output RST

This patch adds two new features:

  * Output is now in RST format
  * Ansible roles in OSA are diffed as well

The RST output makes it easier to copy/paste the output into release
notes, documentation, or other RST-formatted items.

The script also diffs the Ansible roles that are installed along with
OpenStack-Ansible. These were helper roles in Liberty and earlier,
but they include the IRR roles in Mitaka and beyond.

Example output: https://gist.github.com/major/b371aba29720748ab6e1e55a2bf164ab

Change-Id: I863a29fad5e56e02a9f47b015ac71867b16e4060

commit_message:
objects: adding an update method to virtual_interface

Adding a save method to the virtual_interface object
and an update method to its database model.

Partially implements blueprint virt-device-role-tagging
Co-authored-by: Artom Lifshitz <alifshit@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I52673fc297cb578995be5c7a075c5693b0793bf5

commit_message:
api-ref: added docs for microversion 2.26

Part of bp:tag-instances
Part of bp:api-ref-in-rst

Change-Id: Ifd0d518d086719eb248b442359c272b1799544c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/89/327089/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. -*- rst -*- .. needs:parameter_verification .. needs:example_verification .. needs:body_verification ============================= Server tags (servers, tags) ============================= Lists tags, creates, replaces or deletes one or more tags for a server, checks the existence of tag for a server. Tags have the following restrictions: - Tag is a Unicode bytestring no longer than 60 characters. - Tags are case sensitive. - '/' is not allowed to be in a tag name - Comma is not allowed to be in a tag name in order to simplify requests that specify lists of tags - All other characters are allowed to be in a tag name - Each server can have up to 50 tags. List Tags ========= .. rest_method:: GET /servers/{server_id}/tags Lists all tags for a server. Normal response codes: 200 Error response codes: unauthorized(401), itemNotFound(404) Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - server_id: server_id_path Response -------- **Example List Tags:** .. literalinclude:: ../../doc/api_samples/os-server-tags/v2.26/server-tags-index-resp.json :language: javascript Add a Single Tag ================ .. rest_method:: PUT /servers/{server_id}/tags/{tag} Adds a single tag to the server if server has no specified tag. Response code in this case is 201. If the server has specified tag just returns 204. Normal response codes: 201, 204 Error response codes: badRequest(400), unauthorized(401), itemNotFound(404) Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - server_id: server_id_path - tag: tag Response -------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - Location: tag_location Replace Tags ============ .. rest_method:: PUT /servers/{server_id}/tags Replaces all tags on specified server with the new set of tags. Normal response codes: 200 Error response codes: badRequest(400), unauthorized(401), itemNotFound(404) Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - server_id: server_id_path - tags: tags **Example Replace Tags:** .. literalinclude:: ../../doc/api_samples/os-server-tags/v2.26/server-tags-put-all-req.json :language: javascript Response -------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - tags: tags **Example Replace Tags:** .. literalinclude:: ../../doc/api_samples/os-server-tags/v2.26/server-tags-put-all-resp.json :language: javascript Check Tag Existence =================== .. rest_method:: GET /servers/{server_id}/tags/{tags} Checks tag existence on the server. If tag is exist returns response with status code 204. Otherwise returns 404. Normal response codes: 204 Error response codes: unauthorized(401), itemNotFound(404) Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - server_id: server_id_path - tag: tag Delete a Single Tag =================== .. rest_method:: DELETE /servers/{server_id}/tags/{tag} Deletes a single tag from the specified server. Normal response codes: 204 Error response codes: unauthorized(401), itemNotFound(404) Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - server_id: server_id_path - tag: tag Delete All Tags =============== .. rest_method:: DELETE /servers/{server_id}/tags Deletes all tags from the specified server. Normal response codes: 204 Error response codes: unauthorized(401), itemNotFound(404) Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - server_id: server_id_path

commit_message:
Change user_id and project_id to 255 length

In case keystone is used with LDAP the user_id/project_id can be more
than 60 characters. This will cause the issue that users cannot create
any share-network or security_service.

Change-Id: I2e2ccce32bf31850c9ffd74d9612cf5237d782fe
Closes-bug: #1594824

commit_message:
policy: Add defaults in code (part 5)

Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code

Change-Id: I3c400b774ce7fb5a59e6523cfbc9e3ba4d4730c1

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_policy import policy from nova.policies import _common BASE_POLICY_NAME = 'os_compute_api:server-metadata' get_name = _common.get_name_partial(BASE_POLICY_NAME) server_metadata_policies = [ policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('index'), check_str=_common.RULE_ADMIN_OR_OWNER), policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('show'), check_str=_common.RULE_ADMIN_OR_OWNER), policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('create'), check_str=_common.RULE_ADMIN_OR_OWNER), policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('discoverable'), check_str=_common.RULE_ANY), policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('update_all'), check_str=_common.RULE_ADMIN_OR_OWNER), policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('delete'), check_str=_common.RULE_ADMIN_OR_OWNER), policy.RuleDefault( name=get_name('update'), check_str=_common.RULE_ADMIN_OR_OWNER), ] def list_policies(): return server_metadata_policies

subject: Fix the init command global conf dir path
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-21 18:50:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/8fe9821a159887080ccabb67ebaeb9147901c99f', 'message': "Fix the init command global conf dir path

This commit fixes how we use the global configuration path as part of
the tempest init command. The concept behind the global config dir is
that is used as an initial preseed of the local etc/ dirs that get
used in each workspace. However, right now the init command relies on
python packaging to try and figure out where this dir lives. This is
because we implicitly are relying on the data_files construct in the
python packaging ecosystem to create this global configuration dir.
This however is a mistake and causes nondeterminism and lots of bugs
because python packaging is never consistent in how it handles these.

Instead of futily attempting to guess where python might put the data
files and hoping that we got it right, this commit switches to an
opinionated stance on where these directories live, it becomes a
documented set of places and the burden is switched to the installer
and or user to make sure these directories are correctly populated.
While this requires an extra step in some installation scenarios it's
a necessary extra step to ensure things actually work. As part of
this change it was also necessary to update certain functions to be
more resilient against the absence of any files in the global config
dir.

Partially-Implements: bp tempest-run-cmd
Change-Id: Ic4e67362db053848e6ad03b0eae9e55faa87766f

commit_message:
Fix the init command global conf dir path

This commit fixes how we use the global configuration path as part of
the tempest init command. The concept behind the global config dir is
that is used as an initial preseed of the local etc/ dirs that get
used in each workspace. However, right now the init command relies on
python packaging to try and figure out where this dir lives. This is
because we implicitly are relying on the data_files construct in the
python packaging ecosystem to create this global configuration dir.
This however is a mistake and causes nondeterminism and lots of bugs
because python packaging is never consistent in how it handles these.

Instead of futily attempting to guess where python might put the data
files and hoping that we got it right, this commit switches to an
opinionated stance on where these directories live, it becomes a
documented set of places and the burden is switched to the installer
and or user to make sure these directories are correctly populated.
While this requires an extra step in some installation scenarios it's
a necessary extra step to ensure things actually work. As part of
this change it was also necessary to update certain functions to be
more resilient against the absence of any files in the global config
dir.

Partially-Implements: bp tempest-run-cmd
Change-Id: Ic4e67362db053848e6ad03b0eae9e55faa87766f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/29/332429/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: There are 3 dirs that get tried in priority order. First is /etc/tempest, if that doesn't exist it looks for a tempest dir in the XDG_CONFIG_HOME dir (defaulting to ~/.config/tempest) and last it tries for a ~/.tempest/etc directory. If none of these exist a ~/.tempest/etc directory will be created. user_xdg_global_path = os.path.isdir(os.environ.get( 'XDG_CONFIG_HOME', os.path.expanduser('~/.config/tempest'))) user_global_path = os.path.join(os.path.expanduser('~'), '.tempest/etc') if os.path.isdir(global_conf_dir): elif os.path.isdir(user_xdg_global_path): return user_global_path elif os.path.isdir(user_global_path): return user_global_path else: os.mkdir(user_global_path) return user_global_path if not config_parse.has_section('DEFAULT'): config_parse.add_section('DEFAULT') conf_generator = os.path.join(config_dir, 'config-generator.tempest.conf') if os.path.isfiledir(conf_generator):
deleted_lines: Returns the correct default config dir to support both cases of tempest being or not installed in a virtualenv. Cases considered: - no virtual env, python2: real_prefix and base_prefix not set - no virtual env, python3: real_prefix not set, base_prefix set and identical to prefix - virtualenv, python2: real_prefix and prefix are set and different - virtualenv, python3: real_prefix not set, base_prefix and prefix are set and identical - pyvenv, any python version: real_prefix not set, base_prefix and prefix are set and different real_prefix = getattr(sys, 'real_prefix', None) base_prefix = getattr(sys, 'base_prefix', None) prefix = sys.prefix if (real_prefix is None and (base_prefix is None or base_prefix == prefix) and os.path.isdir(global_conf_dir)): # Probably not running in a virtual environment. # NOTE(andreaf) we cannot distinguish this case from the case of # a virtual environment created with virtualenv, and running python3. # Also if it appears we are not in virtual env and fail to find # global config: '/etc/tempest', fall back to # '[sys.prefix]/etc/tempest' else: conf_dir = os.path.join(prefix, 'etc/tempest') if os.path.isdir(conf_dir): return conf_dir else: # NOTE: The prefix is gotten from the path which pyconfig.h is # installed under. Some envs contain it under /usr/include, not # /user/local/include. Then prefix becomes /usr on such envs. # However, etc/tempest is installed under /usr/local and the bove # path logic mismatches. This is a workaround for such envs. return os.path.join(prefix, 'local/etc/tempest') if os.path.isdir(config_dir): conf_generator = os.path.join(config_dir, 'config-generator.tempest.conf')

Make code line length less than 79 characters

Lines should be wrapped at 79 characters.

TrivialFix

" "   ." msgid "" "Each OpenStack release has a code name. commit_message:
fix fullstack errors in CI

In current fullstack test cases of SG in test_apps.py,
the codes assumed that fixed IP addresses of VM ports
wound begin with the value of network prefix plus three.
That can't be guaranteed by the DHCP sever. Directly get
the IP address of a already created VM port may be the
right way.
Besides, this patch also fix errors in test_pub_sub by
creating the chassis with a format in accordance with
current implementation in codes.

Change-Id: I0d5ec66072696fa481d052360fdd35304ec76a8c
Closes-Bug: #1595465
Closes-Bug: #1595800

subject: Allow auth plugins to be setup more than once
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 19:31:38.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/tests/unit/ksfixtures/auth_plugins.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/5dfa16a5cfeb302db22207f27be524266c0bd2ca', 'message': 'Allow auth plugins to be setup more than once

I originally thought this was a good idea and long term I think it is.
The problem is that some tests need to use this fixture in the test
method itself and that will run after `load_backends()`, which also
tries to setup auth plugins.

This should come back after the tests are in good enough shapre to
support it.

Change-Id: I1175fa95d128940eb1a0feebdfe5d6e16285ad0a
'}]
commit_message:
Allow auth plugins to be setup more than once

I originally thought this was a good idea and long term I think it is.
The problem is that some tests need to use this fixture in the test
method itself and that will run after `load_backends()`, which also
tries to setup auth plugins.

This should come back after the tests are in good enough shapre to
support it.

Change-Id: I1175fa95d128940eb1a0feebdfe5d6e16285ad0a

commit_message:
Implement gate-puppet-openstack-spec-helper-syntax

Create Implement gate-puppet-openstack-spec-helper-syntax (puppet 3 and 4)
that will run Puppet syntax tests against puppet-openstack_spec_helper,
like we already do with lint, unit and beaker.

Depends-On: Ia845567f5b3fa0c3e6c063126eddf95378708909

commit_message:
Implement gate-puppet-openstack-spec-helper-lint

Create gate-puppet-openstack-spec-helper-lint job that will run Puppet
lint tests against puppet-openstack_spec_helper, like we already have
beaker & unit tests.

Change-Id: Ibf90806a0b1ee92cfdd1ea948d0ca102781900cf
Depends-On: Ica12fcd31500bbca98df5f581e93b541b7a9372d

commit_message:
Fix Monasca Analytics python27 job

Current python27 job fails because it cannot solve dependencies for
Spark. This patch installs non-distro packages for python27 job.

Change-Id: Ieb258ef2f4a5a158720f5fc0d5b62b3b46267103

subject: policy: Add defaults in code (part 1)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-13 05:56:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7202b0321d4803f5917b894becd899ed3901d7f8', 'message': 'WIP: policy: Add defaults in code (part 1)

Change-Id: I7a7dc2a111d536380a763169320a0820b0715a11
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-14 00:04:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b791b668d74e10ed5aeea5c3e9f99bab6145c2f0', 'message': 'policy: Add defaults in code (part 1)

Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code

Change-Id: I7a7dc2a111d536380a763169320a0820b0715a11
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-06-14 12:10:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c17fa5b8c7fac32b52f3c941f3abe94f7737d905', 'message': 'policy: Add defaults in code (part 1)

Adds default values for policy rules in code and removes
them from etc/policy.json file. The change is validated
by the nova.tests.unit.test_policy unit tests.

Registers default policy rules in the newly created
policy enforcer.

Some policy rules have a TrueCheck condition, which
always return True (e.g.: discoverable rules, server-tags
rules). This causes the unit test
test_enforce_admin_actions_with_nonadmin_context_throws
to fail, as it expects a PolicyNotAuthorized exception.
Those rules have to be skipped.

Co-Authored-By: Andrew Laski <andrew@lascii.com>

Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code

Change-Id: I7a7dc2a111d536380a763169320a0820b0715a11
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-06-14 20:01:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3726a3bf18d798c76657560c45bcddd4cdc0e3da', 'message': "policy: Add defaults in code (part 1)

Adds default values for policy rules in code and removes
them from etc/policy.json file. The change is validated
by the nova.tests.unit.test_policy unit tests.

Registers default policy rules in the newly created
policy enforcer.

Adds 'authorize' method in nova.policy.

Adds 'can' method in nova.context.RequestContext, which
checks if a given rule and target passes the policy
requirements.

Updates nova.api.openstack.compute modules to use the
context's 'can' method instead of the existing
'authorize' function.

Some policy rules have a TrueCheck condition, which
always return True (e.g.: discoverable rules, server-tags
rules). This causes the unit test
test_enforce_admin_actions_with_nonadmin_context_throws
to fail, as it expects a PolicyNotAuthorized exception.
Those rules have to be skipped.

Co-Authored-By: Andrew Laski <andrew@lascii.com>

Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code

Change-Id: I7a7dc2a111d536380a763169320a0820b0715a11

commit_message:
policy: Add defaults in code (part 1)

Adds default values for policy rules in code and removes
them from etc/policy.json file. The change is validated
by the nova.tests.unit.test_policy unit tests.

Adds default policy rules in policy_fixture. The policy_fixture
is currently loading an incomplete set of policy rules (from
policy.json or fake_policy), resulting in unit tests running
with an incomplete set of policy rules.

Co-Authored-By: Andrew Laski <andrew@lascii.com>

Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code

Change-Id: I7a7dc2a111d536380a763169320a0820b0715a11

commit_message:
Expose classifier driver pre-commit error to the user

The precommit driver method should fail the creation of a flow classifier
if it does not match the specific driver limitations and conditions.
In this case, we should expose the drivers exception to the user, so he/she
can know what needs to be fixed.
The general error does not help the user.

Change-Id: I27e9e10548af65c4866a301c37ad8bcca436ef47

commit_message:
Add missing coordination=True on service start

In the main() for starting the volume service, the coordination
param needs to be passed on Service.create when
CONF.enabled_backends is False. This is already being done when
all cinder services are starting up, so just an oversight.

Change-Id: I036e3baf15d848125e115e9f146af1c930c6faba
Closes-Bug: #1594835

commit_message:
tempest: Add Unicode volume name test

Create and view a volume with Unicode characters
in the name.

Change-Id: I0c49814a98921d9743f74a6fc0b0b0044473c398
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/25/310925/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2016 Red Hat, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.volume import base as volume_base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.common import waiters from tempest import config CONF = config.CONF class CinderUnicodeTest(volume_base.BaseVolumeTest): @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(CinderUnicodeTest, cls).resource_setup() # Stick to three-byte unicode here, since four+ byte # chars require utf8mb4 database support which may not # be configured. cls.volume_name = u"CinderUnicodeTest" cls.volume = cls.create_volume_with_args(name=cls.volume_name) @classmethod def create_volume_with_args(cls, **kwargs): name = kwargs['name'] or data_utils.rand_name('Volume') name_field = cls.special_fields['name_field'] kwargs[name_field] = name volume = cls.volumes_client.create_volume(**kwargs)['volume'] cls.volumes.append(volume) waiters.wait_for_volume_status(cls.volumes_client, volume['id'], 'available') return volume def test_create_delete_unicode_volume_name(self): """Create a volume with a unicode name and view it.""" result = self.volumes_client.show_volume(self.volumes[0]['id']) fetched_volume = result['volume'] self.assertEqual(fetched_volume[self.special_fields['name_field']], self.volume_name)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-23 16:36:17.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e4dc81f005c9e7407ae12b39932e538de66c27c1', 'message': "Handle UnableToAutoAllocateNetwork in _build_and_run_instance

project (if one is not already available or requested).

For Neutron this most likely means something has gone wrong
in the deployment (since we checked a dry-run that we could do
this in the API) and rescheduling isn't going to fix it, so we

Change-Id: I2b04ef162192c0448e881c505b15d28ba585be19
"}]
commit_message:
Handle UnableToAutoAllocateNetwork in _build_and_run_instance

The network API will raise UnableToAutoAllocateNetwork if,
well, it's unable to automatically allocate a network for the
project (if one is not already available or requested).

For Neutron this most likely means something has gone wrong
in the deployment (since we checked a dry-run that we could do
this in the API) and rescheduling isn't going to fix it, so we
want to abort the server build and put it into ERROR state.

Part of blueprint get-me-a-network

Change-Id: I2b04ef162192c0448e881c505b15d28ba585be19

commit_message:
Implement volume actions

The purpose of this patch set is to provide the end users with
the following functionalities:
1. Extend the size of the specified volume.
2. Set attachment metadata of the specified volume.
3. Update state of the specified volume.
4. Set image metadata of the specified volume.
5. Unset image metadata of the specified volume.
6. Show image metadata of the specified volume.

Change-Id: Ie9e4ca15a412c89a3c44f1b8526e6597eddf762c

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Huawei Tech. Co., Ltd. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from mock import patch import pecan import unittest from cinderclient.client import HTTPClient from oslo_utils import uuidutils from tricircle.cinder_apigw.controllers import volume_actions as action from tricircle.common import constants from tricircle.common import context from tricircle.common import exceptions from tricircle.db import api from tricircle.db import core from tricircle.db import models class FakeResponse(object): def __new__(cls, code=500): cls.status = code cls.status_code = code return super(FakeResponse, cls).__new__(cls) class VolumeActionTest(unittest.TestCase): def setUp(self): core.initialize() core.ModelBase.metadata.create_all(core.get_engine()) self.context = context.Context() self.project_id = 'test_project' self.context.tenant = self.project_id self.controller = action.VolumeActionController(self.project_id, '') def _prepare_pod(self, bottom_pod_num=1): t_pod = {'pod_id': 't_pod_uuid', 'pod_name': 't_region', 'az_name': ''} api.create_pod(self.context, t_pod) b_pods = [] if bottom_pod_num == 1: b_pod = {'pod_id': 'b_pod_uuid', 'pod_name': 'b_region', 'az_name': 'b_az'} api.create_pod(self.context, b_pod) b_pods.append(b_pod) else: for i in xrange(1, bottom_pod_num + 1): b_pod = {'pod_id': 'b_pod_%d_uuid' % i, 'pod_name': 'b_region_%d' % i, 'az_name': 'b_az_%d' % i} api.create_pod(self.context, b_pod) b_pods.append(b_pod) return t_pod, b_pods def _prepare_pod_service(self, pod_id, service): config_dict = {'service_id': uuidutils.generate_uuid(), 'pod_id': pod_id, 'service_type': service, 'service_url': 'fake_pod_service'} api.create_pod_service_configuration(self.context, config_dict) pass def _prepare_volume(self, pod): t_volume_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() b_volume_id = t_volume_id with self.context.session.begin(): core.create_resource( self.context, models.ResourceRouting, {'top_id': t_volume_id, 'bottom_id': b_volume_id, 'pod_id': pod['pod_id'], 'project_id': self.project_id, 'resource_type': constants.RT_VOLUME}) return t_volume_id def _prepare_server(self, pod): t_server_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() b_server_id = t_server_id with self.context.session.begin(): core.create_resource( self.context, models.ResourceRouting, {'top_id': t_server_id, 'bottom_id': b_server_id, 'pod_id': pod['pod_id'], 'project_id': self.project_id, 'resource_type': constants.RT_SERVER}) return t_server_id @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_action_not_supported(self, mock_context): mock_context.return_value = self.context body = {'unsupported_action': ''} res = self.controller.post(**body) self.assertEqual('Volume action not supported', res['Error']['message']) self.assertEqual(400, res['Error']['code']) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_action_volume_not_found(self, mock_context): mock_context.return_value = self.context body = {'os-extend': ''} res = self.controller.post(**body) self.assertEqual('Volume not found', res['Error']['message']) self.assertEqual(404, res['Error']['code']) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_action_exception(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id mock_action.side_effect = exceptions.HTTPForbiddenError( msg='Volume operation forbidden') body = {'os-extend': {'new_size': 2}} res = self.controller.post(**body) # this is the message of HTTPForbiddenError exception self.assertEqual('Volume operation forbidden', res['Error']['message']) # this is the code of HTTPForbiddenError exception self.assertEqual(403, res['Error']['code']) mock_action.side_effect = exceptions.ServiceUnavailable body = {'os-extend': {'new_size': 2}} res = self.controller.post(**body) # this is the message of ServiceUnavailable exception self.assertEqual('The service is unavailable', res['Error']['message']) # code is 500 by default self.assertEqual(500, res['Error']['code']) mock_action.side_effect = Exception body = {'os-extend': {'new_size': 2}} res = self.controller.post(**body) # use default message if exception's message is empty self.assertEqual('Action os-extend on volume %s fails' % t_volume_id, res['Error']['message']) # code is 500 by default self.assertEqual(500, res['Error']['code']) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_extend_action(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context mock_action.return_value = (FakeResponse(202), None) t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id body = {'os-extend': {'new_size': 2}} res = self.controller.post(**body) url = '/volumes/%s/action' % t_volume_id mock_action.assert_called_once_with(url, body=body) self.assertEqual(202, res.status) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_attach_action(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context mock_action.return_value = (FakeResponse(202), None) t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) t_server_id = self._prepare_server(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id body = {'os-attach': { 'instance_uuid': t_server_id, 'mountpoint': '/dev/vdc' }} res = self.controller.post(**body) url = '/volumes/%s/action' % t_volume_id mock_action.assert_called_once_with(url, body=body) self.assertEqual(202, res.status) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_reset_status_action(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context mock_action.return_value = (FakeResponse(202), None) t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id body = {"os-reset_status": { "status": "available", "attach_status": "detached", "migration_status": "migrating" }} res = self.controller.post(**body) url = '/volumes/%s/action' % t_volume_id mock_action.assert_called_once_with(url, body=body) self.assertEqual(202, res.status) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_set_image_metadata_action(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context mock_action.return_value = (FakeResponse(202), None) t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id body = {"os-set_image_metadata": { "metadata": { "image_id": "521752a6-acf6-4b2d-bc7a-119f9148cd8c", "image_name": "image", "kernel_id": "155d900f-4e14-4e4c-a73d-069cbf4541e6", "ramdisk_id": "somedisk" } }} res = self.controller.post(**body) url = '/volumes/%s/action' % t_volume_id mock_action.assert_called_once_with(url, body=body) self.assertEqual(202, res.status) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_unset_image_metadata_action(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context mock_action.return_value = (FakeResponse(202), None) t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id body = {"os-unset_image_metadata": { 'key': 'image_name' }} res = self.controller.post(**body) url = '/volumes/%s/action' % t_volume_id mock_action.assert_called_once_with(url, body=body) self.assertEqual(202, res.status) @patch.object(pecan, 'response', new=FakeResponse) @patch.object(HTTPClient, 'post') @patch.object(context, 'extract_context_from_environ') def test_show_image_metadata_action(self, mock_context, mock_action): mock_context.return_value = self.context mock_action.return_value = (FakeResponse(202), None) t_pod, b_pods = self._prepare_pod() self._prepare_pod_service(b_pods[0]['pod_id'], constants.ST_CINDER) t_volume_id = self._prepare_volume(b_pods[0]) self.controller.volume_id = t_volume_id body = {"os-show_image_metadata": None} res = self.controller.post(**body) url = '/volumes/%s/action' % t_volume_id mock_action.assert_called_once_with(url, body=body) self.assertEqual(202, res.status) def tearDown(self): core.ModelBase.metadata.drop_all(core.get_engine())

commit_message:
Add security_compliance group back to config

When we migrated to keystone.conf, the security_compliance group
was missed. This patch adds it and fixes a small name error.

Change-Id: I173f1dd7122eb3e388d623f97cf019588edb2c6f

commit_message:
Add support to tune the keystone apache MPM settings

This fix adds support to tune the apache MPM server settings
in case more HTTP threads are needed.

New overrides have been predefined in order to use the Ubuntu
default settings:

     keystone_httpd_mpm_backend: event
     keystone_httpd_mpm_start_servers: 2
     keystone_httpd_mpm_min_spare_threads: 25
     keystone_httpd_mpm_max_spare_threads: 75
     keystone_httpd_mpm_thread_limit: 64
     keystone_httpd_mpm_thread_child: 25
     keystone_httpd_mpm_max_requests: 150
     keystone_httpd_mpm_max_conn_child: 0

Change-Id: Ieaad4d2b3c62a5b59e1fa597816ab1b4c2fc3cb1
Closes-Bug: #1576399
